bibl.title: Despatch from Samuel S. Sevier to Thomas F. Bayard
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p:
Consulate General of the U.S.
Monrovia Dec. 31, 1886

Mr. S. S. Sevier
To the Secty. of State.
Returns for a quarter ending Dec. 31, 1886, also yearly returns.

I have the honor to transmit herewith returns of this Consulate General for the quarter ending Dec. 31, 1886. You will note that my Abstract of Contingent Expenses is very large; that this is
is owing to the great amount of afects of the widow of the late Minister Moses A. Hopkins I had to ship back to her home in N.C.

The returns are as follows: Departure and arrival of American vessels (1); Summary of business of this Consulate General (2) Digest of Invoice Book (3); Treasury Fees (4); Abstract of Contingent Expenses with vouchers (5); Statement of account (6); Statement of account for official Cablegram (7); Names of persons employed
at the Consulate (8); List of Despatches sent to the Department of State (9); Aggregate return of fees at this Consulate for the year (10); Agricultural and Commercial report of Liberian produce (11).
I hope these returns will receive the approval of the Department of State.

I am Sir
Your obedient servant
Sam'l S. Sevier
Acting U.S. Consul Gen.

1 Departure and Arrival of American vessels; 2. Summary of business of this Consulate
3. Treasury Fees
4. Abstract of Contingent Expenses.
5. Statement of account.
6. Statement of account for Cablegram
7. Names of persons at the Consulate.
8. Despatches sent to Department.
9. Aggregate returns of fees.
10. Agricultural and Commercial report.
11. Digest of Invoice Book.

div1.head: Liberian Commerce and Agriculture.
div1.p:
The commerce of the country during the year was much impaired by the recent depression in trade. The palm oil, palm kernals, coffee, and ginger, having fallen below their market value, have discouraged the Natives to such an extent, that they refuse to make the palm oil, palm kernals; and plant their ginger crop. The Americo-Liberian Farmers– the greater bulk–have neglected to clean their coffee plantations; and gather their coffee crop. The nominal sum of twenty five cents per gallon, for palm oil in trade goods, which is equivalent to
twelve cents per gallon United States currency. Palm kernals Eighty cents per bushel, which is equivalent to Forty cents per bushel United States currency. Coffee and ginger ten cents per pound which is also equivalent to five cents United States currency. All tend to discourage the makers and producers. The refusal of the Natives, and Americo-Liberians, to make, and gather, these important articles of commerce, of which there are no other substitutes for their deficiencies, has caused a considerable decrease, in the commerce of the country. There was a considerable quantity of American provisions and dry goods shipped via
Hamburg to Liberia in German steamers by American agencies in Hamburg and in return the palm oil, and palm kernals were shipped to Hamburg sold and proceeds shipped to the United States; but owing to the depression of trade, there has been quite a decrease in this Americo-German trade with Liberia. There is a great demand for American goods in Liberia, and her interior settlements; but owing to the lack of steam communication between the United States and Liberia; and the lack of a demand in the United States, for the raw products of Liberia, Liberian merchants are compelled to carry on, the greatest
bulk of their trade, with the English manufacturers of Manchester, and Liverpool. There is likely to be a further decrease, in the price of coffee, the coming season. The English market where the greatest bulk of Liberian coffee is shipped, is being flooded with a great quantity, Brazilian, Java, & Venezuelian coffee, which is not superior to Liberian coffee, in size, strength, or flavor, but in curing. The Liberian Farmers not taking the necessary care in curing their coffee for the market which causes the coffee to be depreciated in value. This is also the case with the ginger, which is not allowed the necessary time for drying, hence when
packed, shipped, and sold is inferior to the ginger of other countries.

div2.head: Agriculture.
div2.p:
This important branch of industry, has taken a sudden vise during the year; owing I suppose to the depression of trade. The people–especially the heathen Liberians–have seen fit to employ themselves in this branch of industry. Throughout the county of Montserrado, which is the largest county in Liberia, can be seen hundreds of acres, of rice, and corn, and numerous other tropical vegetables; under cultivation.
So numerous were these articles of home consumption; that they were offered at the capital Monrovia–for trade goods– Iron pots, Tobacco, Brass kettles, Powder, Guns & Gin which were never sold before but for United States Greenbacks, or coins, English, Dutch, & German Gold, and Liberian Coppers. Many of these tropical vegetables could become important articles of commerce, especially the cassada which makes a starch much superior arrowroot. There is also a great abundance of arrowroot which grows wild could be cultivated and made an important article of
commerce. There are much wealth, and treasures, hidden, and undeveloped, in Liberia; which American Capitalists, Manufacturers, Agriculturalists, and Mineralogists, could utilise for their benefit; and increase American commerce. There is no reason why the United States could not control, the great bulk of Liberian trade. If Americans would exert themselves in this direction there would be much gain to us. The people–Americo-Liberians and Heathen Liberians all prefer American goods and would far rather exchange with the Americans than with those they do.

United States Consulate General
Monrovia Dec. 1886

Sam'l S. Sevier
Acting Consul Gen.
